question.body: Consider again the two scenarios and studies from question 1 (but ignore the information about the p-value of the test corresponding to study I). Which of the following (if any) is not possible (at the .05 significance level)?

multiple_choice.choice: Ho is rejected in both tests.
Ho cannot be rejected in both tests.
Ho cannot be rejected in test I, but is rejected in test II.
Ho is rejected in test I, but cannot be rejected in test II.
Any of the above is a possibility.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Recall that the p-value of the two-sided test is twice the p-value of a one-sided test (based on the same data). It could be the case, like in question 1, where the p-value of test I is .024 and the p-value of test II is therefore .024/2 = .012. In both cases, the p-value is small enough to reject Ho (at the .05 significance level).

Incorrect. Recall that the p-value of the two-sided test is twice the p-value of a one-sided test (based on the same data). It could be the case for example, that the p-value of test I is .24 and the p-value of test II is therefore .24/2 = .12. In both cases the p-value Ho cannot be rejected (at the .05 significance level).

Incorrect. Recall that the p-value of the two-sided test is twice the p-value of a one-sided test (based on the same data). It could be the case, for example, that the p-value of test I is .07 (i.e., not small enough for Ho to be rejected at the .05 significance level), and the p-value of test II is therefore .07/2 = .035 which is small enough to reject Ho at the .05 significance level.

Good job! Recall that the p-value of the two-sided test is twice the p-value of a one-sided test (based on the same data). If Ho can be rejected in test I (at the .05 significance level), it means that the p-value is below .05. This implies that since the p-value of test II must be, then, below .05/2 = .025, Ho will also be rejected in that test. There is no way, then, that Ho can be rejected in the two-sided test and not rejected in the one-sided test.

Incorrect. Recall that the p-value of the two-sided test is twice the p-value of a one-sided test (based on the same data). This means that if the p-value of the two-sided test is small, then the p-value of the one-sided test is even smaller.
